TITLE I--CHIEF HUMAN CAPITAL OFFICERS

This Act, known as the "Good People, Good Government Act," establishes Chief Human Capital Officers and a Council, requires a report on human capital metrics, and includes reforms for federal employee career development and benefits. "CHAPTER 14--CHIEF HUMAN CAPITAL OFFICERS" - This chapter establishes Chief Human Capital Officers and a Council, requiring a report on human capital metrics and including reforms for federal employee career development and benefits. Establishment of Chief Human Capital Officers in Executive agencies to advise on workforce management and implementation of regulations. Authority includes setting the workforce development strategy. The Chief Human Capital Officer's responsibilities include setting the agency's workforce development strategy, assessing future workforce needs, reviewing HR policies, promoting continuous learning, identifying best practices, and measuring intellectual capital for organizational performance. Each Chief Human Capital Officer has access to necessary records and reports. The Chief Human Capital Officer has access to all relevant records, reports, and documents, can request information from government entities, and can enter into contracts for studies and services as needed. The Chief Human Capital Officer can request information or assistance from Federal entities and report any unreasonable refusals to the head of the establishment. The Chief Human Capital Officer can request information or assistance from Federal entities without delay. A clerical amendment is made to the table of chapters for part II of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 102. CHIEF HUMAN CAPITAL OFFICERS COUNCIL. The Chief Human Capital Officers Council is established, consisting of the Director of the Office of Personnel Management as chairperson, the Deputy Director of the Office of Management and Budget, and Chief Human Capital Officers of Executive departments. The Council advises and coordinates agency activities on human resources modernization, information quality, and relevant legislation. SEC. 103. REPORT ON HUMAN CAPITAL METRICS FOR THE FEDERAL GOVERNMENT. The General Accounting Office will conduct a study and prepare a report on developing human capital metrics for the Federal Government. The report will examine the feasibility of creating standardized measurements for efficiency and success in achieving human capital objectives among Federal agencies. The General Accounting Office will submit a report on human capital metrics for Federal agencies to the Senate and House committees within 1 year of the Act's enactment. The report aims to facilitate agency comparison and management focus on human capital issues. It may also serve as a basis for regular reports by Chief Human Capital Officers. SEC. 104. EFFECTIVE DATE. This title will take effect 180 days after enactment, except for Section 103 which will be effective immediately. TITLE II--REFORMS RELATING TO FEDERAL EMPLOYEE CAREER DEVELOPMENT AND BENEFITS SEC. 201. AGENCY TRAINING. The amendment requires agency heads to evaluate and modify training programs to achieve specific goals. Additionally, agency heads must appoint a training officer to assist in fulfilling their responsibilities. The amendment mandates agencies to establish training programs for developing managers and managing employees with unacceptable performance. Agencies must also maintain detailed records of all training activities. Chapter 41 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to include new training program requirements for managers and employees with unacceptable performance. Chapter 41 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to include new training program requirements for managers and employees with unacceptable performance. Specific training programs and records maintenance are outlined, including provisions for academic degree training under subsection (b) of section 4107. The regulations prescribe that agencies may provide training or reimbursement for training costs that contribute significantly to meeting agency needs, resolving staffing problems, or achieving strategic goals. The agency employee development program must be linked to achieving goals and administered by an accredited educational institution. Agencies must consider maintaining a diverse workforce in line with merit system principles. The curr_chunk discusses the representation of disabilities in Government service and the provision of education and training for employees. It also specifies limitations on the exercise of authority for certain positions. The curr_chunk amends section 902(a)(6) of title 31, United States Code, by including expenditures on agency training as a separate statement in accountability reports. SEC. 202 amends title 5, United States Code, by adding CHAPTER 30 on recruitment authority. Chapter 30 of title 5, United States Code establishes recruitment authority for agencies. It defines an agency as an Executive agency, requires the appointment of recruitment officers by agency heads, and mandates the maintenance of detailed recruitment records by each agency. Additionally, agency recruiting activities must be reported separately in accountability reports. In Chapter 30 of title 5, United States Code, agency recruiting authority is established, with requirements for appointing recruitment officers, maintaining recruitment records, and reporting recruiting expenditures separately in accountability reports. Amendments include redesignating subparagraphs and inserting a new subparagraph for expenditures on agency recruiting. The heading and analysis for subpart B of part III of title 5, United States Code, are amended to read as "Recruitment, Employment, and Retention." Additionally, there is an increase in government contribution for federal employee health insurance. The government is increasing the maximum contribution payable for federal employee health insurance, with amendments to sections 8906(b)(1) and 8906(b)(2) of title 5, United States Code. The changes will take effect on the first day of the first contract year after the enactment of the Act.
